citing_paper_authors: Sebastian, Padó | Gemma, Boleda
raw_text: As argued in Section 3.4, our aim in this experimentis to control for the most plausible sources of performance variance and isolate the influence of argument structure. To meet this condition, we perform both the experiments and the uniformity measure calculation on a controlled subset of the data, with the condition that both the number of verbs and the number of sentences are the same for each frame. Following the methodology in Keller and Lapata (2003), we divide the verbs into four frequency bands, frequency being absolute number of annotated sentences: low (5), medium-low (12), medium-high (22), and high (38)
clean_text: Following the methodology in Keller and Lapata (2003), we divide the verbs into four frequency bands, frequency being absolute number of annotated sentences: low (5), medium-low (12), medium-high (22), and high (38).

raw_text: Thus, the frequency of appearance of n-grams on the Web (via the Google search engine) appears as a good indicator of the n-gram popularity/soundness (Keller and Lapata, 2003). In our case, a n-gram is a segment of the nominalized constituent, constituted by the nominalized past participle (NPP) and by the preposition followed by the short complement (i.e. reduced to the common noun)
clean_text: Thus, the frequency of appearance of n-grams on the Web (via the Google search engine) appears as a good indicator of the n-gram popularity/soundness (Keller and Lapata, 2003).
